newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean won ends higher on BOK intervention.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean won ends higher on BOK intervention.

text.p: Intervention by the central Bank of Korea (BOK) in forward trading pushed the won to close higher on Tuesday, dealers said.
But they forecast consolidation would be short-lived in the local market, given the dollar's bullishness in world markets.
The won closed at 869.30 after opening at 869.90. The won rose to 867.60 after the intervention.
"It's true the intervention made dollar buying interest weak today. But many doubt its long-term effect," said a domestic bank dealer.
"Without central bank intervention, the greenback would have climbed over the 870.00 won level today," said a foreign bank dealer.
Dealers said BOK sold more than $200 million today, selling mostly in six-month forward trading.
They described the intervention as "absurd" because the dollar's persistent strength against other currencies including the yen and the mark rendered the bank's efforts useless.
"The won/dollar rate will soon fluctuate in line with movement in the world market," another local bank dealer said.
Thursday's mid-rate is expected to be pegged at between 868.50 and 868.70 against 869.30 today. -- Y.J. YEOM
